item.title: [02] R shiny: Create login page
item.description:
Implementing a typical login page can be quite complex in R shiny. Implementing such a typical login page requires handling user information and passwords, which presents limitations when building it in R Shiny. This post demonstrates how to create a “login page” in an R Shiny app. More precisely, it might be more appropriate to call it a simulated login page.

For example, you could create a feature that takes guests from the login page to the main UI page by simply entering their email address. Furthermore, you can even have your visitors receive a notification via email as soon as they enter their email address.

item.title: [01] R shiny: Dashboard UI
item.description:
R shiny is a very useful and versatile tool to build your own app using R. This blog section will walk you through the step-by-step process of how the GAM tool app was built. Please note that your R environment and package versions may differ from mine. Today’s topic will cover how the basic UI was set up.

To begin, let’s set up a simple shiny application with a basic UI and server structure. Before creating the app, ensure you have the necessary libraries installed. If not, you can install them using:

item.title: [00] R shiny: Getting started
item.description:
R Shiny

R Shiny is an open-source R package that allows users to build interactive web applications directly in R without requiring extensive knowledge of web development (HTML, CSS, or JavaScript). It is widely used for data visualization, dashboard creation, and interactive analytics. Shiny applications run in a web browser and can be hosted locally, on Shiny Server, or deployed to ShinyApps.io or other cloud platforms. R Shiny is a game-changer for those who want to create interactive applications and data-driven dashboards without needing deep web development expertise. Whether you’re an analyst, researcher, or developer, Shiny provides a powerful and flexible way to bring your data to life.

item.title: GAM tool using R shiny
item.description:
https://smoke.shinyapps.io/rsGAM/

Purpose of tool

The purpose of this app is to demonstrate the application of General Additive Modeling (GAM) for predicting MDA8 O3 using meteorological data under both smoke and non-smoke conditions. In this app, a GAM is derived using the "mgcv" package in R. We hope this tool will be useful for state agencies and others in understanding the factors that control ozone production.

Example page in the GAM tool app

The GAM is a statistical or machine learning framework that provides interpretability by applying smoothing functions to individual variables. Notably, GAMs can incorporate linear, nonlinear, and categorical predictors, providing flexibility for modeling complex relationships (Wood, 2017). In particular, such statistical/machine learning models can provide an efficient tool for analyzing air quality, especially in relation to wildfire smoke. For example, O3 can be used as the response variable, modeled using meteorological data, satellite-derived measurements, and/or backward air trajectories (Lee and Jaffe, 2024). This study demonstrated the importance of wildfire smoke as contributors to exceedances of the health-based national air quality standards for PM2.5 and O3. This app offers options to easily build a GAM using the "mgcv" package (Wood, 2023) and also allows viewing the results of previously studied GAMs.

item.title: PhD. Haebum Lee
item.description:
Postdoctoral Scholar

Jaffe Group,
School of STEM,
University of Washington (UW),
Bothell, WA, United States

        

Hello, and Welcome to my Blog! I am a scientist who focus on the multifaceted study of air quality and atmospheric phenomena, including the analysis of wildfire smoke on ozone, air pollutant monitoring, and the utilization of satellite and remote sensing data to assess atmospheric parameters. I am also deeply engaged in studying the physicochemical properties of atmospheric aerosols, the dynamics of new particle formation (NPF), and the development of predictive models using machine learning.

This blog is to explain R technologies and how to integrate them into your research. I hope everything is useful, thank you.

item.title: Resources
item.description:
Useful data archives

  • AerosolWatch: Aerosol-related satellite data mapping by NOAA NESDIS STAR: Center for Satellite Applications and Research
  • AirNow-Tech: A platform for analyzing real-time and historical air quality data from the US monitoring network
  • AirNow-Tech archive: A repository for real-time and historical air quality data from the US monitoring network
  • Copernicus CAMS: Provides global atmospheric composition data, forecasts, and reanalysis from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS)
  • Copernicus Hub: A portal for accessing satellite imagery and Earth observation data from the Copernicus program
  • EPA AQS API: API intructions for retrieving air quality data collected by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
  • EPA AQS pre-generated data: A collection of pre-processed air quality datasets available for bulk download
  • EPA PM2.5 tiering tool: A tool for classifying PM2.5 air pollution events based on their severity and regulatory significance
  • IEM ASOS network: Iowa Environmental Mesonet (IEM) Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS) Network, "riem" package in R
  • NASA GES DISC: A data archive providing global climate, weather, and atmospheric datasets from NASA missions
  • NASA GSFC: A resource for satellite-based NO2 data from NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center
  • NASA Giovanni: An online data analysis tool for visualizing and exploring NASA’s atmospheric and climate datasets
  • NASA MERRA-2 archive: A respitory for Modern-Era Retrospective analysis for Research and Applications, Version 2 (MERRA-2)
  • NASA POWER: A website for NASA Prediction Of Worldwide Energy Resources (POWER) project
  • NOAA GOES-R: A website for NOAA Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites—R Series (GOES-R)
  • NOAA GOES-R GG cloud: A Googel Cloud for NOAA Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites—R Series (GOES-R)
  • NOAA GOES-R AOD: A respitory for NOAA GOES-R Series Advanced Baseline Imager (ABI) Level-2 Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD)
  • NOAA HRRR: A website for NOAA High-Resolution Rapid Refresh (HRRR) Model
  • NOAA HRRR parameters: Parameter descriptions for NOAA High-Resolution Rapid Refresh (HRRR) Model
  • TEMIS: Tropospheric Emission Monitoring Internet Service (TEMIS)
  • TEMPO: Tropospheric Emissions Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO)
  • TEMPO CosmicDS : Tropospheric Emissions Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) CosmicDS NO2 viewer
  • TEMPO EPA : EPA’s Remote Sensing Information Gateway for TEMPO
  • TROPOMI-L2 NOAA: Download TROPOMI Level-2 Data Files from the S5P Data Hub
  • TROPOMI-L2/3 PAL: Copernicus Sentinel-5P Product Algorithm Laboratory (S5P-PAL) Data Portal (Level-2 and Level-3)

Resources for spatial information

  • NOAA NCEI Geographical Reference Maps: A website for NOAA NCEI Geographical Reference Maps
  • US Census Bureau: TIGER/Line Shapefile, Current, Nation, US, Core-Based Statistical Areas
  • USDOT BTS: US Department of Transportation: ArcGIS Online, Core-Based Statistical Areas

Resources for wildfire information

  • NRC: A website for Natural Resources Canada (NRC)
  • NIFC: A website for National Interagency Fire Center (NIFC)
  • Science Northwest: A blog on environmental science, air quality, and climate change (Dr. Jaffe, UW)
  • WFEIS: Wildland Fire Emissions Inventory System (WFEIS) - assessments of historical wildland fire emissions across US, Canada, and global boreal regions

Resources for models

  • EPA AERMOD: A Gaussian air dispersion model used for estimating air pollutant concentrations from industrial sources
  • FLEXPART: FLEXible PARTicle dispersion model (FLEXPART)
  • STILT: Stochastic Time-Inverted Lagrangian Transport Model v2.x (STILT)
